Beautiful story, beautiful movie_ŸŒ¸ I have a story to share with you. For a long time I had planned to see this movie, (mostly because Eddie Redmayne is my favorite actor since 2012 when I saw him in Les Miserables) but it never happened ,you know what I mean? This year I finally decided to watch it,  and I loved it! It was like I got to know Stephen, sure I had heard of him before, but I suddenly learned so much more. I was completely blown away by this story, and the music was something extremely powerful that I always cried to, and I couldnâ€™t stop listen to it.About 2 days later the news were everywhere, and it for real broke my heart. Stephen is no longer with us, but I think heâ€™s sitting up there somewhere, still exploring the universe_Ÿ’«âœ¨ He was a brilliant man, he knew what he was doing and had a head that is too unbelievable to understand. I feel kind of cursed because of this, how can he pass away 2 days later, just when I got to know him??... It all started with the execution of one specific equation and the equation expanded to the infinity forming so called universe, and concept of material.Just like how mandelbrot set works, it starts with a simple mathematical equation where you can execute in any programming language, you get more and more details as you iterate through the equation.Our understandings are only limited to our sensory organs, and the things we perceive are only the by-product of first execution of the specific equation.This was just a philosophical approach to the origin of everything and an attempt to explain what happened just before the big bang occured, to sum it up all, the initial fractal pattern that was originated from the equation caused an infinite set of fractal branches what we call "the big bang", every first fractal branches that's originated from the first body fractal is a universe and the other branches that's originated from these "universe fractal branches" are the matter, "matter" branches ramify to what we perceive, the material, the third dimension.From what we know about the fractals, the first iteration of the fractal ramifies to two more branches, so the first two branches are the first and only two universes that will ramify to everything else.ï»¿

When I was on my own world of Art, I started to think about movies I could watch. I stumble upon this movie. 'The Theory Of Everything'. I thought, cool, I can watch watch this for like all day. So, I put down my pencil and my sketch pad, mainly focus on the device, and watch it. I realized, it was the life of Stephen Hawking! Cool! I nver knew that he had this kind of life. Sad, happy, etc. He inspired me to love Science even more because at my 1st year of High School, one of my weaknesses is Science, along with Math. I then started to research about his life and his studies. I watched the movie over, and over, and over again. I even followed Eddie's other films like Fantastic Beast and Where To Find Them, etc. It was so spectacular to make a movie just like that. A week before my final exam in 1st year High School, I studied and studied and studied. Of course especially at Science. In my head was like, 'Yes, Science! I learned everything for me! Thanks, Mr. Hawking! ' I also watched the movie, even tge behind the scenes. But the day after, as I was browsing the best side of YouTube, this videi showed up. 'The Final Words Of Stephen Hawking'. I was like, what? That couldn't be happening,right? I click on the video. It was said he dued on March 14th of 2018 (or something), tge exact day I studied for Science. I feel all of the things that are heavy weigh me down like an ant being weighed down by a huge rock. No. This can't be happening. How?! I feel like I loss so much power and life. On the day of the exam at Science, I couldn't forget what I've heard. But most importantly I can't forget what have he done to the society. He helped people who have difficulties ib understanding about space and time. I still can't believe that he is dead now. In fact, Stephen died like a hero. R. I. P.  Stephen Hawking. We love you all.ï»¿

Zameen Z I accept that science has not yet discovered everything. But I'm sure that it will. Who knew 300 years ago that one day we were going to discover the quantum mechanical model of the atom, and the wave nature of matter. These thoughts must have been bizarre at that time. But experiments point out again and again that fundamental particles behave both as particles and waves. Same with light. If someone was told 300 years ago that everything is made of small particles which are actually partially wave, he/she wouldn't have given a damn to such a bizarre concept. Similarly, today the idea of particles being created from nothing may sound bizarre, but it will be proved in the future, I guarantee that. Meanwhile, if you talk of a creator, that theory is full of loopholes and contradictions. The universe is complex, and if it had a creator, the creator must be even more complex. So even the creator must have a creator by your logic. And that creator must also have a creator... The chain never ends. All the organisms You see on Earth are a result of evolution. People ask for evidence of evolution. I ask them the evidence against evolution. Can't you see the gradual improvement in cell structure from bacteria to the first eukaryotes? The embryos of humans and fishes are identical, which indicates common ancestory at some point. I can't put this 100s of pages worth evidence in this comment. But wish I could.ï»¿

Sorry i dont want to waste anyone's time but I just need to share my story. Sometimes when I'm at school I like to separate myself from the rest of my class. Not by walking away but just by stop listening to the sounds around me and stop looking at the things around me. Normaly I look outside to the trees, the birds and the big , undiscovered sky above me.. but I didn't look at it two days ago. Two days ago I looked at a big poster on the wall for half an hour without looking away; 'The Theory of Everything' it said. I knew it was a movie before. But that day, two days ago I couldn't get my eyes of the poster. I looked Into eddies eyes, wandering away in my own thoughts. A few hours later, after dinner, I had to study for my math exam but I just couldn't stay focussed. My mind was with the poster and I felt like I had to watch it before continuing with my normal life. That night I couldn't sleep so I opened my window. I looked up and I had never seen a sky like that before. I saw more stars than ever before and they shined brighter than ever before. I started thinking: 'what is everything?' At that moment I opened my laptop and I put on this movie. I'll be honest with you all. I was very very touched. I laughed but I also had tears in my eyes because I was sad. Especially when I saw the scene where Jane said that she had loved Stephen, and Stephen started crying, I felt so bad. At that moment my phone vibrated, of course I didn't take a look at it because I was so focussed on the movie. But at the end, when I had just seen his life backwards. And the beautiful credit music started, I looked out my window again with the tears still in my eyes. Than I grabbed my phone and I saw this one pop up in my screen. 'Stephen Hawking passed away'. I was shocked. I was angry but. I was crying like a little baby. I changed. I wanted to go and live my life to it's fullest potential. I wanted to Discover the universe, and find the meaning of it all. Please, if you are still reading. Noting and noone can stop you from being the person that you want to be. Please, don't try to be popular and don't be afraid to be yourself. You can only find answers about life if you live how you want to live.Thanks, good luck. And rest in Peace Stephen âù_ï»¿

Stephen HawkingThe interesting fact is that Stephen Hawking was born 8th January 1942 and I was born 8th January 1996, so Stephen Hawking is 54 years older than me. Time, Space. Time-Space. Science. Technology...Of course when he is a scientist. The theory of everything is the sun: the sun heats and heats up and by the action of sending out heat,it produces its own nucleus and builds pressure inside of it. And when the sun heats,it releases pressure from the nucleus to the shell/covering. These steps are called 'pulse of heat' (beating of heat emanating from the sun). Our hearts make pulses of heat; engines make pulses of heat; lamps make pulses of heat; batteries make pulses of heat. Everything that consumes energy,sends out pulses of heat! This is also the reason why you see the nucleus and rings that the sun pruduces everywhere in nature. For example, when you throw a stone into a body of water, at the place where the stone lands, we see the shape of a nucleus and the rings emanating outward from the nucleus. The form of all living things is also a core(heart) And a circle(covering/skin). The shape of a plant also contains a nucleus(of the plant seed) and an encircling(shell of the fruit or stem leaves of the flower. By jekaï»¿

M. Robitaille's nullification of Kirchoff's Law on which the Planck constant is derived &, in turn,  on which Einstein's relatvity is derived, thus nullifying the claims of both Planck & Einstein. "Our time" implies anyone who was still alive until any moment between now and 30 years ago, because 30 years is the average age of people alive today; physicist is anyone who likes physics; celebrated is anyone with notable achievements in physics. So it's right to say Stephen Hawking isn't the one holding this prize. I don't know who is the most celebrated, but I know Stephen Hawking isn't him because you can quickly find other that surpass him. Even when i only consider physicists who were alive until the day this trailer was published, Stephen Hawking is not the greatest, and the problem of "Who is the greatest physicist alive today" is a hard one, but I can safely claim he isn't the one.ï»¿
@Leo Sousa He is the most mainstream oneï»¿

@Christ David Well yes, that's just how things are: When you try to solve the biggest questions on the edge of known things, then you will inevitably run into the situation that you have to build up theories based on less and less evidence and the probability of making mistakes grows exponentially. So a "big bang theory" is infinitely more fragile and likely to be only partially true or entirely false  than let's say evolution. Evolution similarly started out as a theory, but today we can safely accept it as a fact because of the immense and overwhelming evidence we have gathered in the last hundred years.So really the question is, do you have a better theory other than the big bang, which is supported my more evidence and working with it you can make more precise predictions about other yet unknown things?ï»¿

+Neo Alpha Ultra Man Theory of everything is also known as string theory which is trying to combine general relativity (law of gravity) and Quantum Mechanics (law of gravity but then for subatomic particles) into 1 theory/formula. It has nothing to to with god ...ï»¿

+Neo Alpha Ultra Man I'm here to answer you and also to correct some of the previous comments.First of, space-science...? WTF is that? I mean, I don't want to sound disrespectful, but I never use words that i don't know what they mean, and so would have to do everybody.Second, I don't know why that is the title of the film, but I can tell you it has nothing to do with any scientific theory. I think that it's more about the meaning of the life itself, and since the life is everything, I suppose that's why they named it this way.Third, +Ramiro Gonzalez and +John Beton, there's no theory in physics or in science known or referred to as the theory of everything. What you're talking about, Ramiro, is the unified field theory, which is not finshed yet, in fact, it's almost not even begun, and it's not a tehory of everything. The purpose of this theory is to try to unify the four fundamental forces (gravity, electrodynamic force, weak nuclear force and strong nuclear force). And John, the string theory is just one theory of the whole lot of theories that are trying to explain everything, so no, it's not called the theory of everything. There's not even a single string theory, there are a few of them. And by the way, I don't think the string theory is the correct one. I think that quantum field theory will result to be the only one correct.I hope to have helped. :)ï»¿

+Neo Alpha Ultra Man The "theory of everything" would be an equation which explains the entire universe. No one can get more specific because this equation has not been discovered yet.Stephen hawking is a cosmologist. This means that he looks for underlying rules of the universe. The reason he often appears in context with space (as in the area outside our atmosphere) is that a lot of cosmology can be studied only by looking into space. Black holes for instance have properties which can not be observed on earth (otherwise we would be in BIG trouble).Also, due to the universe expanding at around the speed of light (recent evidence points to this expansion being faster), we can "look back in time" and observe the universe in the past.There is a lot more to this, and I only know as much as pop-science literature and high school science teaches me.If you want to learn more about the topic look at quantum physics, string theory and relativity.About explaining away god: Yes, if such an equation were to be discovered, we could explain how the universe came to be the way it is now from the very beginning. We could explain EVERYTHING. Literally. That's why it's called theory of everything. This would make the concept of a creator obsolete, since there would be no more gaps in scientific understanding to be filled.And don't grammar nazi me to avoid dealing with the content of this comment.ï»¿
